notes_1: Permission simple notes: Described as printer specialising in devotional works and based in rue Saint-Jacques in 1781 Almanach de la Librairie, but as Libraire in the Permission Simple registers. This is still probably the same Morin, however, as in 1783 Benoît Morin went bankrupt and had to cede his printshop. Continued in trade til 1802. Seems to be only Morin trading in Paris at time granted permission simple. Dates trading in Paris Nov. 1772 to 1717 (as printer-bookseller Nov 1772-1783; as bookseller thereafter).
Customs register signatory might be Benoi?t Morin, who suffered a couple of confiscations around this time, but lack of signature or other confirmatory evidence mean this is only conjecture.

Succeeded Pierre Bruyset Ponthus. Permission simple notes: Recorded as a bookselling business in the Almanach de la Librairie for 1781, although J.-M. Bruysset the father is also listed as a Printer in the same source. Presumably this is because the son gained permission to serve as a bookseller in 1768 but was only received as a printer in 1783. Early permission simples attributed to J.-M. Bruysset probably therefore refer only to the father. The father-son partnership apparently lasted from 1774 to c. 1791 according to Mellot et al. The older Jean-Marie Bruysset traded from c. 1744 to c.1791 and died in 1793; the younger Jean-Marie Bruysset, the eldest of his sons, was condemned to death in the Terror for printing 'billets obsidionaux' during the siege of Lyon, but his brother Pierre-Marie died in his place (25-12-1793) and he lived on until 1817.

Bruyset imprimeur-libraire could at this date apply to Jean-Marie Bruyset, pere, (1719-1793); his son Jean-Marie Bruysset (1744-1817), who became a printer in 1784, or their business partnership. Due to these ambiguities, this reference has been treated as a separate client.

notes_1: It has been assumed that the many references to Bastilliot, Batilliot and Batillot in the confiscation register, all dating from period 1778-1784, refer to the same person. However, no external references to booksellers of this me prior to 1790 are found in CERL. Thereafter examples in Paris and Cap François. Unusually, Batilliot never signed the register himself, and his works were collected by several different agents, thought the mes A. Huin, Lavocat, and Petit recur.

Permission simple notes: Listed in the Almanach de la Librarie for 1781 merely as a bookseller med Racine. Mellot et al say his presence in Rouen is attested from April 1781 and that he was an associate, then from Sept / October 1783 successor, to the bookseller Pierre Machuel, trading from the latter's address in rue de la Ganterie. Racine remained in business til around 1805, though in 1803 sold part of fonds. Died 1814

Printer-bookseller at Poitiers from c.1776-c.1818. Almanach de la Librarie for 1781 lists him as business partner of Jean-Felix Faulcon, his father-in-law, whom he succeeded as printer in 1783. A permission given to a François Barbier supposedly of Saumur was clearly intended for the Poitiers printer, and so the data has been corrected in the actual place of publication.

Permission simple notes: Richard-Gontran Lallemant [or Lallemand / l'Allemand] was med as a printer-bookseller in the 1781 Almanach de la Librairie and according to Mellot et al. was in business 1754 to c. 1790. Son of Nicolas Lallement, who resigned in his favour in 1754, and received printer in place of another printer in the same year. Ennobled by letters patent (1775) when gained a hereditary privilege over printing in Rouen - hence his imprint 'l'Imprimerie privile?gie?e' and variants. Died 1807.

notes_1: At date of this entry, Louis-Pierre was only Couret de Villeneuve in the trade according to CERL. Permission simple notes: Listed as printer-bookseller, Couret de Villeneuve, fils, in the Almanach de la Librarie for 1781; Mellot et al. clarfiy that he traded at Orleans from 1771 to 1794, when he went into liquidation (though also established at Paris 1791-8 and in Orleans again 1797) and gained his printer's status in 1776. Earliest two permissions to Couret de Villeneuve, dating from 1797, could possibly belong to his father, Martin Couret de Villeneuve (died 21 October 1780), who was also a printer-bookseller at Orleans. Louis-Pierre was also successor to his father and brother in law to the media baron Charles-Joseph Panckoucke.

notes_1: Customs register signatory might be Benoi?t Morin, who suffered a couple of confiscations around this time, but lack of signature or other confirmatory evidence mean this is only conjecture.
notes_2: Permission simple notes: Described as printer specialising in devotional works and based in rue Saint-Jacques in 1781 Almanach de la Librairie, but as Libraire in the Permission Simple registers. This is still probably the same Morin, however, as in 1783 Benoît Morin went bankrupt and had to cede his printshop. Continued in trade til 1802. Seems to be only Morin trading in Paris at time granted permission simple. Dates trading in Paris Nov. 1772 to 1717 (as printer-bookseller Nov 1772-1783; as bookseller thereafter).
Listed as retired in 1781 Almanach de la librairie.

This 'sieur George', whose fonds de la librairie were ceded to Sr Lesclapart and sold in 1772 has not been further identified, whether through Mellot et al, Worldcat imprint data and searches for his me in conjunction with other booksellers with whom he is known to have done business (Lesclapart, Desventes of Dijon).
Name is hard to decipher. Des Esard in the customs register.

notes_1: Probably Jean-Marie Bruysset, père, as he was a printer at the time of the Permission simples granted to J.-M. Bruysset and his eldest son, also Jean-Marie, was not. But could equally refer to J.-M. Bruysset, Pere et fils, the business that they ran in common from c. 1774 to 1791, or possibly to the son. The STN client J.-M. Bruysset being described simply as 'libraire' was presumably the son. The Almanach de la Librairie 1781 lists the father separately as a printer from the father/son business, which is listed only as a bookseller's. As a result the entries for 'J. M. Bruysset' in the permission simple register are treated as a separate client.
notes_2: Succeeded Pierre Bruyset Ponthus. Permission simple notes: Recorded as a bookselling business in the Almanach de la Librairie for 1781, although J.-M. Bruysset the father is also listed as a Printer in the same source. Presumably this is because the son gained permission to serve as a bookseller in 1768 but was only received as a printer in 1783. Early permission simples attributed to J.-M. Bruysset probably therefore refer only to the father. The father-son partnership apparently lasted from 1774 to c. 1791 according to Mellot et al. The older Jean-Marie Bruysset traded from c. 1744 to c.1791 and died in 1793; the younger Jean-Marie Bruysset, the eldest of his sons, was condemned to death in the Terror for printing 'billets obsidionaux' during the siege of Lyon, but his brother Pierre-Marie died in his place (25-12-1793) and he lived on until 1817.

notes_1: Roger me possibly Royer.

Joseph(II) Carez (1752-1801) was the son of Joseph (I) Carez and according to seems  (according to CERL) to have taken over his father's business from his mother in 1781 or 1782 (the Almanach de la Librairie for 1781 lists the widow rather than father or son). Unfortunately the STN archival guides make no distinction between Joseph Carez (I) and Joseph Carez (II), treating them as one individual, so that the correspondence and hence transaction events relating to both are associated with just one client. That practice has been discontinued in the Permission Simple dataset: father and son are treated as separate individuals.
notes_2: Mellot et al./CERL give Joseph (I) Carez's life dates as c.1720-c.1781, and note that he was established at Toul from 1751 as a printer-bookseller, following decree of royal council (20 Sept. 1751). His widow is listed as printer-bookseller in 'Almanach du Libraire' for 1781 but it appears his son, Joseph Carez (II), (1752-1801), returned to Toul and took over later in same year. Unfortunately the STN archival guides make no distinction between Joseph Carez (I) and Joseph Carez (II), treating them as one individual, so in FBTEE-1.0 the correspondence and hence transaction events relating to both men are associated with just one client. That practice has been discontinued in the Permission Simple dataset. A lone January 1781 permission has been assumed to relate to Joseph (I) Carez. Toul's book trade was under the jurisdiction of the Chambre Syndicale of ncy, so a set of permissions granted to 'Carez, impr. of ncy' on 2 December 1778 clearly relate to Joseph (I) Carez. It is also possible, that he carried out his trade from ncy for a short while at this time.

notes_1: Lally-Tollendal seems to be indicated by reference to Lally as well as Lally-Tollendal. The place of origin of one of the confiscated 'Arrets du Conseil d'Etat' - Rouen - is strong circumstantial evidence that they related to the posthumous retrial of Lally-Tollendal's father Thomas Arthur Lally before the Parlement of Rouen, which opened in 1788, shortly before the confiscation. It ran to 1781. Lally-Tollendal had been campaigning for his father's posthumouos acquittal ever since his execution in 1766. Only person of this surname at time.

Additional documents - 1 'circulaire', 1 'prospectus' 23/12/1777. Confiscations notes: Turot was presumably the Paris bookseller of that me who appears in STN data (1777) with address in the rue du Roi de Sicile. On line searches reveal Turot (who described himself as a negociant) in 1778 was receiving subscriptions at this address for 'L'Esprit des journaux', the 'Mercure de France' and the 'Affiches, annonces et avid divers, ran the bureau de correspondance for the 'Journal Encyclopedique' and 'L'Esprit de Journaux'. He was possibly the same person as radical journalist Joseph Turot (died 1825), who is listed in CERL and published 'Gazette tionale' in the 1790s. However, further searches in CERL, Worldcat and online have not elicited reveal further information to confirm Turot's identity, and the confiscation associated with him does not relate to his traffic in periodical literature.

notes_1: Active 1763-1788; also known as Charles-Pierre Berton.
notes_2: Identification after Mellot et al. Active 1763-1788. Confiscations notes: Only Paris bookseller med Berton listed in CERL. Life dates 1730-1788: master bookseller from 30 April 1763 and in trade til May 1788 when sold most of 'Fonds' to Eugene Onfroy for 153,000 livres. Died Paris December 1788. Signature evidence suggests that in instances where Berton signed confiscations or customs register is in a single hand with distinctive flourishes (this accounts for 8 out of 9 confiscations linked to Berton); one signed record states 'Berton, libraire'. Berton was son of Gabriel-Charles Berton, Paris bookseller, (1696-1757).

notes_1: Confiscation register entries to Guyot probably relate to multiple persons. Perhaps some entries for Guiot / Guyot relate to Laurent Guyot / Guiot (1756-1808), the only person of this surname operating in print trade anywhere at this time according to CERL: an engraver and distributor of prints, bookseller, printer and publisher according to CERL (except perhaps his brother and business partner Charles, who was working with him by 1788). But CERL dates start of his activity to c.1785 on which makes it hard to link him to confiscations in 1770s.

A printer-bookseller med Danel is listed in the Almanach de la Librairie, 1781, and continued to exercise the trade of printer til 1783. A Danel, fils, is also listed as a bookseller only. Neither is in Mellot et al. All references to Danel in the Permissions registers reveal that he is a 'printer'. The evidence of Barbier, Juratic and Vangheluwe, 'Lumieres du Nord' (p. 255) reveal that this must mean Paul-Liévin-Joseph Danel, to whom we owe a handful of imprints in the me of L. Danel or Liévin Danel in worldcat. Barbier et al. gives his life dates as 1716-1789. The Danel, fils, listed in the Almanach is his son, Albert-Léonard-Joseph Danel, (born 1759), who was received as a bookseller in Lille in 1780 and petitioned to become a printer conjointly with his father in 1782, replacing him on his resignation the following year. He used the imprint Léonard Danel.

notes_1: Permission simple notes: Listed as Imprimeur-Libraire in the 1781 Almanach de la Librairie but according to Mellot et al. retired in favour of his son Henri in March of the same year. Born c. 1710 in Umstadt to German father and mother from Lorraine, and settled in ncy as companion printer around 1735, converting to Catholicism in process. Became a printer-bookseller in his own right in 1754, when he bought one-third of 'fonds' of Abel-Denis Cusson. Died in February 1794. me given as Haner in estampillage data.

notes_2: Permission simple notes: Jean Dupleix was the bookseller to the University of Toulouse, active c1765 to c.1807. Worked in partnership with Simon Sacarau 1765-1768, then following an acrimonious split and lawsuit, with Antoine-Louis-Guillaume-Catherine Laporte from 1769 to 1777 (CERL). By the time he applied for permissions simples he was a sole trader. He is almost certainly the bookseller Dupleix who appears in the STN archives and hence FBTEE-1.0 database as a correspondence of the STN. As with other clients, it is always possible that more than one individual was behind the permission applications.

Stock Sales Notes: Active 1763-1797; it is assumed he is the Hérissant syndic invited to the Garguery stock sale in 1770 and med as Jean-Thomas in the records of the Gueffier sale records (as opposed to his father and mesake who was 66 at the time), but this has not been fully established. Is the same Hérissant as in FBTEE-1 data, as confirmed by address at rue des Fosses-Monsieur-le-Prince. May also be the Hérissant in the 1781 Almanach de la librairie. Seems to be the Hérissant fils in the Babuty sale records (and Durand), as other candidates (including his brother) appear under different forms. Confiscations notes: References to Hérissant fils in the confiscation registers appear to refer to Jean-Thomas Hérissant fils as distinct from Claude-Jean-Baptiste Hérissant (also fils), since C.-J.-B. is designated elsewhere in this and other documents as Hérissant rue N [Notre dame], and his father was long dead so unlikely to be known as 'fils' at this time. Four of five documents related to Hérissant fils bear similar distinctive signature, so clearly relate to one person.

Confiscations notes: Turot was presumably the Paris bookseller of that me who appears in STN data (1777) with address in the rue du Roi de Sicile. On line searches reveal Turot (who described himself as a negociant) in 1778 was receiving subscriptions at this address for 'L'Esprit des journaux', the 'Mercure de France' and the 'Affiches, annonces et avid divers, ran the bureau de correspondance for the 'Journal Encyclopedique' and 'L'Esprit de Journaux'. He was possibly the same person as radical journalist Joseph Turot (died 1825), who is listed in CERL and published 'Gazette tionale' in the 1790s. However, further searches in CERL, Worldcat and online have not elicited reveal further information to confirm Turot's identity, and the confiscation associated with him does not relate to his traffic in periodical literature.

notes_1: Permission simple notes: Listed as Imprimeur-Libraire in the 1781 Almanach de la Librairie but according to Mellot et al. retired in favour of his son Henri in March of the same year. Born c. 1710 in Umstadt to German father and mother from Lorraine, and settled in ncy as companion printer around 1735, converting to Catholicism in process. Became a printer-bookseller in his own right in 1754, when he bought one-third of 'fonds' of Abel-Denis Cusson. Died in February 1794. me given as Haner in estampillage data.

Active c. 1784-1823. birth date approx. after Mellot et al. Only officially received into guild in 1786. Confiscations notes: Jean-François Royer or Royez (or occasionally Royès) was the only Paris-based (or French) bookseller with the me Royer / Royez at this period. CERL says he was active from 1784, when me the starts appearing in confiscations registers frequently (although there is one entry in October 1783). He remained active til 1823. Yet there remain some residual doubts about the author/owner of books in these entries. The only signature that we can attribute beyond reasonable doubt to Jean-François Royez is a chronological outlier, dating from 1781 when he collected a consignment of books for Lamy, to whom he was then apprenticed.  That signature has a distinctive opening R in particular that differs from the later signatures, which could nevertheless have evolved into a lazier version of the same shape. For the most common variant - signature variant 4 in these notes, this seems to be confirmed by the existence of a book with the Royez imprint in one 1789 Royez confiscation: this seems to confirm that Royez was the booksellers. This type 4 signature resembles the 1781 signature in most other features. The other signatures are also broadly similar, but one has a pronounced 'z'. Given the evidence of me variants it is possible that the still youthful Jean-François was experimenting with signatures as well as spellings of his me. This conclusion is supported by several entries marked 'Royez, libraire' in MS 21,935 which bear variant signatures. It remains possible that the Royez signatures represent more than one individual.
notes_2: Additional documents - 2 'factures a.s.' 19/11/1774 & 15/06/1776.

notes_1: Confiscation register entries to Guyot probably relate to multiple persons. Perhaps some entries for Guiot / Guyot relate to Laurent Guyot / Guiot (1756-1808), the only person of this surname operating in print trade anywhere at this time according to CERL: an engraver and distributor of prints, bookseller, printer and publisher according to CERL (except perhaps his brother and business partner Charles, who was working with him by 1788). But CERL dates start of his activity to c.1785 on which makes it hard to link him to confiscations in 1770s.

Items attributed to Nyon [all unidentified] cannot be definitively linked to either 'Nyon jeune' or, via, 'Nyon ainé' to 'Saillant et Nyon' or to other Nyon's in trade, whether through evidence of signatures, agents collecting consignments, or ballot marques. The confiscation registers do not explicitly mention 'Nyon jeune' in any entry (though from shape of signatures, it is possible he signed consistently for Nyon aine's consignments). Agents collecting these unattributed consignments are different from those collecting for Saillant et Nyon or Nyon ainé.

notes_1: Active c. 1772-1790. Not in Mellot et al. Imprints appear in her me in Worldcat from 1773-1790. Appears to be the Vallat-la-Chapelle indicated in stock sale of Boudet in 1787. STN correspondence lists apparent partnership Vallat la Chapelle & Vve in correspondence with the STN from 1772-1774. In effect this was presumably a sequential correspondence - veuve Vallat-la-Chapelle published in her own me only from her husband's death; there is no sign of a male relative being involved in the trade. Her daughter Marie-Rozalie Huzard succeeded her. Vve Vallat-la-Chapelle has been recorded as a separate person here. It has also been assumed that Vve La Chapelle invited to Lottin stock sale in 1783 is Vve Vallat La Chapelle. Confiscations notes: Only Vallat la Chapelle active at this period.

notes_2: The Société typographique de Londres, run by the Genevan exile David Boissière, had a commercial alliance with Gosse fils and although never trading directly with the STN, almost certainly received their books via Gosse. notes_1: Permission simple notes: Listed as Imprimeur-Libraire in the 1781 Almanach de la Librairie but according to Mellot et al. retired in favour of his son Henri in March of the same year. Born c. 1710 in Umstadt to German father and mother from Lorraine, and settled in ncy as companion printer around 1735, converting to Catholicism in process. Became a printer-bookseller in his own right in 1754, when he bought one-third of 'fonds' of Abel-Denis Cusson. Died in February 1794. me given as Haner in estampillage data.

notes_1: Name given as Chesnaut in Babuty sale records, so identification from Mellot et al. is not quite certain.
notes_2: Additional document - 1 'prospectus du 30/08/1777'. Confiscations notes: Described as 'libraire à Meaux' in MS Fr 21,935 at fo. 19. Almanach de la Librairie (1781) confirms a Charle, libraire at Meaux; Googlebooks has a catalogue of 'Livres qui se trouvent chez Charle, libraire, à Meaux, rue St Rémy' (1776) and gives his Christian me as Charles-Etienne. He advertised as publisher of 'Almanach de Meaux' (1784) and receiving subscriptions for the 'Journal Encyclopedique' in 1791. CERL said his father Charles (died shortly before 1771) was also a bookseller at Meaux, and that Charles-Etienne was active c. 1773 to 1791.

Additional documents - 1 'circulaire', 1 'prospectus' 23/12/1777. Confiscations notes: Turot was presumably the Paris bookseller of that me who appears in STN data (1777) with address in the rue du Roi de Sicile. On line searches reveal Turot (who described himself as a negociant) in 1778 was receiving subscriptions at this address for 'L'Esprit des journaux', the 'Mercure de France' and the 'Affiches, annonces et avid divers, ran the bureau de correspondance for the 'Journal Encyclopedique' and 'L'Esprit de Journaux'. He was possibly the same person as radical journalist Joseph Turot (died 1825), who is listed in CERL and published 'Gazette tionale' in the 1790s. However, further searches in CERL, Worldcat and online have not elicited reveal further information to confirm Turot's identity, and the confiscation associated with him does not relate to his traffic in periodical literature.

notes_1: Confiscation register entries to Guyot probably relate to multiple persons. Perhaps some entries for Guiot / Guyot relate to Laurent Guyot / Guiot (1756-1808), the only person of this surname operating in print trade anywhere at this time according to CERL: an engraver and distributor of prints, bookseller, printer and publisher according to CERL (except perhaps his brother and business partner Charles, who was working with him by 1788). But CERL dates start of his activity to c.1785 on which makes it hard to link him to confiscations in 1770s.

The confiscation registers do not explicitly mention 'Nyon jeune' in any entry (though from shape of signatures, it is possible he signed consistently for Nyon aine's consignments). Agents collecting these unattributed consignments are different from those collecting for Saillant et Nyon or Nyon ainé.

Some Worldcat author entries from 1775 to 1785 (and beyond) give Christian me as Louis. A significant number of editions over period 1772 to 1806 bear the Buchet imprint. A 1787 imprint gives an address: 'rue des Greffes' but by 1788 we have 'la porte de l'Esplanade, place de la Salamandre.' He is not listed in Mellot et al.

notes_1: Jean-Baptiste Hucherot, fils (17? - ?), was the son and successor of Louis Hucherot (23 Feb. 1700-1791) and took over his father's business on Louis Hucherot's retirement in 1771. He was elected adjoint and syndic of the local chambre syndicale in 1774. (Source: M.-H. Clement-Janin, 'Les Imprimeurs et les libraires dans la Cote d'Or', Slatkine reprints, 1971, p. 62). Since the only confiscated consignment associated with Hocherot came from Dijon, this identification seems certain: subsequent and previous generations of the family appear not to have worked in the trade. Louis Hucherot is listed in CERL but Jean-Baptiste is not. The CERL entry on Jean-Baptiste Capel, printer and professor of Rhetoric, say he took over the business from 'Louis Hucherot, fils' in December 1778: could there be some confusion of mes?
notes_2: Permission simple notes: Listed as a printer-bookseller in Almanach de la Librairie, 1781. Mellot et al. reveal he died in March 1782, leaving the business to his widow.

notes_1: Not listed in Mellot et al. Confiscations notes: Jean-Baptiste Gobreau, tive of Sedan, apprenticed to F. Marchenoir 1764, qualified as Paris bookseller 1774 in other MPCE datasets. CERL lists as active as printer with address on Quai des Augustins in 1781-2. Worldcat reveals a couple of dozen editions with his imprint, 1776-1787, several in partnership with Musier (1782-7) and a couple with Legras (c. 1782). Last documentary attestation a patriotic contribution in 1790. All references to Gobreau in dataset assumed to be to this individual (rare me).

notes_1: Desauges signature contains Pierre Desauge's distinctive blade shape. Pierre Desauges was a Parisian colporteur and father of the Versailles bookseller Edme-Marie-Pierre Desauges. Pierre was briefly embastilled in June/July 1760 and again in Jan-April 1775. on the latter occasion, which related to the affair Louise Marichell, his son was arrested the same day. Pierre Desauge's dates in the trade are uncertain, but his son only entered trade in 1773, allowing us to identify Pierre as owner of the signature appearing before that date.
author_of_2: Avantages du mariage : et combien il est nécessaire & salutaire aux prêtres & aux évêques de ce tems-ci d'épouser une fille chrétienne (Bruxelles, Bruxelles)

notes_1: François Buisson was apprenticed to Joseph Cuchet in Grenoble 1766-1785 , but moved to Paris and entered the trade in effect 1782, though only admitted formally as a bookseller following brief apprenticeship to Cuchet's nephew Gaspard-Joseph 26 April-15 July 1785. (Not to be confused with Louis Buisson, who traded in Lyon at slightly earlier period and possibly in Paris in 1789-90: CERL). All but one of the entries relating to Buisson were signed for by Buisson, his younger brother (Buisson le jeune 'pour mon frère'), Pinchedez, the bookseller Dufour, or an overlapping combination of these persons, confirming that they were associated with the one business.

Leclerc, [all unidentified]' relates to customs register entries in the me of 'Leclerc' which could not be positively linked to any known Leclerc of Le Clerc, or one to another. However these entries, like several others in the register, probably all or mostly relate to either Charles-Guillaume Leclerc or  Laurent-François Leclerc, both of whom were Parisian booksellers.

Additional documents - 1 'circulaire', 1 'prospectus' 23/12/1777. Confiscations notes: Turot was presumably the Paris bookseller of that me who appears in STN data (1777) with address in the rue du Roi de Sicile. On line searches reveal Turot (who described himself as a negociant) in 1778 was receiving subscriptions at this address for 'L'Esprit des journaux', the 'Mercure de France' and the 'Affiches, annonces et avid divers, ran the bureau de correspondance for the 'Journal Encyclopedique' and 'L'Esprit de Journaux'. He was possibly the same person as radical journalist Joseph Turot (died 1825), who is listed in CERL and published 'Gazette tionale' in the 1790s. However, further searches in CERL, Worldcat and online have not elicited reveal further information to confirm Turot's identity, and the confiscation associated with him does not relate to his traffic in periodical literature.
There is no evidence to establish whether three confiscations linked to 'Bernard, [all unidentified]' relate to the same person.

notes_1: Active c. 1784-1823. birth date approx. after Mellot et al. Only officially received into guild in 1786. Confiscations notes: Jean-François Royer or Royez (or occasionally Royès) was the only Paris-based (or French) bookseller with the me Royer / Royez at this period. CERL says he was active from 1784, when me the starts appearing in confiscations registers frequently (although there is one entry in October 1783). He remained active til 1823. Yet there remain some residual doubts about the author/owner of books in these entries. The only signature that we can attribute beyond reasonable doubt to Jean-François Royez is a chronological outlier, dating from 1781 when he collected a consignment of books for Lamy, to whom he was then apprenticed.  That signature has a distinctive opening R in particular that differs from the later signatures, which could nevertheless have evolved into a lazier version of the same shape. For the most common variant - signature variant 4 in these notes, this seems to be confirmed by the existence of a book with the Royez imprint in one 1789 Royez confiscation: this seems to confirm that Royez was the booksellers. This type 4 signature resembles the 1781 signature in most other features. The other signatures are also broadly similar, but one has a pronounced 'z'. Given the evidence of me variants it is possible that the still youthful Jean-François was experimenting with signatures as well as spellings of his me. This conclusion is supported by several entries marked 'Royez, libraire' in MS 21,935 which bear variant signatures. It remains possible that the Royez signatures represent more than one individual.

notes_2: Identification after Mellot et al. Active 1763-1788. Confiscations notes: Only Paris bookseller med Berton listed in CERL. Life dates 1730-1788: master bookseller from 30 April 1763 and in trade til May 1788 when sold most of 'Fonds' to Eugene Onfroy for 153,000 livres. Died Paris December 1788. Signature evidence suggests that in instances where Berton signed confiscations or customs register is in a single hand with distinctive flourishes (this accounts for 8 out of 9 confiscations linked to Berton); one signed record states 'Berton, libraire'. Berton was son of Gabriel-Charles Berton, Paris bookseller, (1696-1757).

notes_2: Permission simple notes: Listed as a Printer-Bookseller in the 1781 Almanach de la Librairie and by Mellot et al.. Trading as a commissionaire with STN rather than bookseller, but doubtless same as took thousands of books. Worked in partnership with his oldest son, also Jean Mossy, from 1784 to his retirement c. 1791. Died in 1792. Some later editions listed under me 'Mossy' in the Permission Simple data may thus be joint editions with his son, but note other editions are explicitly attributed to Mossy  père et fils.

notes_2: These entries probably relate to Antoine-Louis-Guillaume-Catherine Laporte, cadet, who according to CERL was the only Laporte trading in Paris at this time according to CERL. The run of entries linked to Laporte in the Confiscation registers begins in 1776, the year of his arrival from Toulouse (where he previously traded). However, as the me is common and there is also an unidentified J. La Porte in the registers, with a very different signature, a few ambiguous records have been attributed to 'Laporte, [all unidentified]' where signature and other evidence is lacking.

notes_1: Items attributed to Nyon [all unidentified] cannot be definitively linked to either 'Nyon jeune' or, via, 'Nyon ainé' to 'Saillant et Nyon' or to other Nyon's in trade, whether through evidence of signatures, agents collecting consignments, or ballot marques. The confiscation registers do not explicitly mention 'Nyon jeune' in any entry (though from shape of signatures, it is possible he signed consistently for Nyon aine's consignments). Agents collecting these unattributed consignments are different from those collecting for Saillant et Nyon or Nyon ainé.

records attributed to 'Merigot, [all unidentified]' could not be linked strongly to any particular member of the Merigot family. A consignment collected by Fournier more likely belonged to Merigot jeune (who received the majority of Merigot consignments) since another of his consignments was also signed for by Fournier, but evidence is insufficient for a certain attribution.
notes_2: It has not been possible to positively identify the Prévost in the Babuty, Vve Garnier and Gueffier pere sale records. Probably one of the existing Prévosts in the database, and likely to be Prévost A./Ainé who was invited to Durand sale a couple of months later. Most of the invitees were the same at both sales. Reference to an invitation to 'et messieurs Guillaume et Prévost at the 1770 Gueffier pere stock sale has been assumed to refer to all Prévosts, but where non-specific, purchases have been recorded under this entry.  Due to context, has been assumed to be a Libraire. Confiscations notes: It has not been possible to positively identify which Prévost(s) are indicated in the records linked to this dealer.

notes_2: Additional documents - 1 'circulaire', 1 'prospectus' 23/12/1777. Confiscations notes: Turot was presumably the Paris bookseller of that me who appears in STN data (1777) with address in the rue du Roi de Sicile. On line searches reveal Turot (who described himself as a negociant) in 1778 was receiving subscriptions at this address for 'L'Esprit des journaux', the 'Mercure de France' and the 'Affiches, annonces et avid divers, ran the bureau de correspondance for the 'Journal Encyclopedique' and 'L'Esprit de Journaux'. He was possibly the same person as radical journalist Joseph Turot (died 1825), who is listed in CERL and published 'Gazette tionale' in the 1790s. However, further searches in CERL, Worldcat and online have not elicited reveal further information to confirm Turot's identity, and the confiscation associated with him does not relate to his traffic in periodical literature.

However, as the me is common and there is also an unidentified J. La Porte in the registers, with a very different signature, a few ambiguous records have been attributed to 'Laporte, [all unidentified]' where signature and other evidence is lacking.
it has not been possible to determine which Desenne these confiscations refer to.

Items attributed to Nyon [all unidentified] cannot be definitively linked to either 'Nyon jeune' or, via, 'Nyon ainé' to 'Saillant et Nyon' or to other Nyon's in trade, whether through evidence of signatures, agents collecting consignments, or ballot marques. The confiscation registers do not explicitly mention 'Nyon jeune' in any entry (though from shape of signatures, it is possible he signed consistently for Nyon aine's consignments). Agents collecting these unattributed consignments are different from those collecting for Saillant et Nyon or Nyon ainé.

Confiscations notes: Turot was presumably the Paris bookseller of that me who appears in STN data (1777) with address in the rue du Roi de Sicile. On line searches reveal Turot (who described himself as a negociant) in 1778 was receiving subscriptions at this address for 'L'Esprit des journaux', the 'Mercure de France' and the 'Affiches, annonces et avid divers, ran the bureau de correspondance for the 'Journal Encyclopedique' and 'L'Esprit de Journaux'. He was possibly the same person as radical journalist Joseph Turot (died 1825), who is listed in CERL and published 'Gazette tionale' in the 1790s. However, further searches in CERL, Worldcat and online have not elicited reveal further information to confirm Turot's identity, and the confiscation associated with him does not relate to his traffic in periodical literature.

notes_1: Bookseller based in rue Ganterie, he is listed in the Almanach de la Librairie for 1781. His imprints in Worldcat span the period 1779-1788, and continue to describe him as libraire (examples in 1783, 1788). Not in Mellot et al. References to 'Ferrand, impr.' in the permission simple records appear to relate to Pierre Ferrand (listed in Almanach of 1781,worldcat editions 1788, 1789, 1780 and beyond; also known in imprints as Pierre Charles Ferrand, fils ainé, libraire) or from 1788 onwards also Jacques Ferrand, who is listed in Mellot and traded from 1788 (whose imprints mention a printshop from 1789). All references to Ferrand libr. have been assumed to be his. (NB. the 1781 Almanach does list two further bookseller Charles David Ferrand and a Ferrand fils: I have not traced any editions to these two individuals during the period of the Permission Simple, so it appears that they were not active in publishing, especially in comparison to Antoine).

Charles Le Père was part of the business partnership Le Père et Avaulez. It was composed of Charles Le Père et Pierre-Michel Avaulez and later his widow. BM data suggests 'Print publishing partnership between Charles Le Père and Pierre Michel Avaulez, from 1772 to 1777; in 1777, Avaulez's widow took over the trade, but died in 1779' and gives trading addresses in both Paris and Rouen: 'A la ville de Rouen', rue St. Jacques près la fontaine St. Séverin, Paris (1773-79) Rue St Jacques vis à vis celle du Plâtre à l'ancienne Poste Rue St Jacques au Papillon'. (https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/search_the_collection_database/term_details.aspx?bioId=120593),  The confiscation register entry reference to Vve Avaulez dates from 1st week of January 1777, suggesting Charles Avaulez perhaps died in 1776. Not in CERL.

notes_1: Register records as Piron by signature gives Pyron. Provenance of confiscated books m(Caen) makes it overwhelmingly likely that this record refers to the Caen bookseller Jean-Claude Pyron. Permission simple notes: Listed as printer-bookseller in Almanach de la Librairie, 1781. Worldcat lists dozens of editions published at Caen from c.1732 to 1785. An edition published by his widow is dated 1787. Appears to have been in partnership with Antoine Cavelier until c. 1743, and to have taken over his business. Described in imprint of 1744 as sole printer of the King, Town and University.

Jean-Baptiste Caron (1747-1752), oldest son of Louis-Charles Caron, printer bookseller, known as Caron l'aîné, Caron fils. A reference to Caron fils in the Permissions simple data almost certainly indicates Jean-Baptiste rather than his brother, who from 1781-9 worked for their father and appears in the registers as Caron jeune or Caron-Berquier.

notes_2: Additional documents - 1 'circulaire', 1 'prospectus' 23/12/1777. Confiscations notes: Turot was presumably the Paris bookseller of that me who appears in STN data (1777) with address in the rue du Roi de Sicile. On line searches reveal Turot (who described himself as a negociant) in 1778 was receiving subscriptions at this address for 'L'Esprit des journaux', the 'Mercure de France' and the 'Affiches, annonces et avid divers, ran the bureau de correspondance for the 'Journal Encyclopedique' and 'L'Esprit de Journaux'. He was possibly the same person as radical journalist Joseph Turot (died 1825), who is listed in CERL and published 'Gazette tionale' in the 1790s. However, further searches in CERL, Worldcat and online have not elicited reveal further information to confirm Turot's identity, and the confiscation associated with him does not relate to his traffic in periodical literature.
There is nothing to positively link the four confiscations from Rey(s) one to another.

notes_1: Items attributed to Nyon [all unidentified] cannot be definitively linked to either 'Nyon jeune' or, via, 'Nyon ainé' to 'Saillant et Nyon' or to other Nyon's in trade, whether through evidence of signatures, agents collecting consignments, or ballot marques. The confiscation registers do not explicitly mention 'Nyon jeune' in any entry (though from shape of signatures, it is possible he signed consistently for Nyon aine's consignments). Agents collecting these unattributed consignments are different from those collecting for Saillant et Nyon or Nyon ainé.
notes_2: Could be Paris clandestine bookseller, Pierre Le Roy (whose status was finally legalised in 1785), or other Le Roys listed in this database, Amable (from Lyon) or Gilles from Caen. All traded across period. All are listed in CERL. Signature match has linked Le Roy libraire to some signatures where his 'libraire' status is not given.

Confiscations notes: As the Barrois family collected consignments for one another on several occasions, all Barrois ownership has been treated as unidentified excepts when Barrois ainé or Barrois jeune is explicitly med as owner in the confiscation register, or signature evidence or postal 'marques' [ballot numbers] seem to indicate one brother or other. Permission simple notes: It is not clear which Barrois brother intended; two of which (Barrois aine? [Louis-François] et jeune [Pierre-The?ophile) are listed separately as bookseller in the 1781 Almanach de la Librairie. Source data merely indicated 'Barrois, libr.'. Thus edition linked to just Barrois is linked to a non-specific 'Barrois' client.

notes_1: Confiscation register entries to Guyot probably relate to multiple persons. Perhaps some entries for Guiot / Guyot relate to Laurent Guyot / Guiot (1756-1808), the only person of this surname operating in print trade anywhere at this time according to CERL: an engraver and distributor of prints, bookseller, printer and publisher according to CERL (except perhaps his brother and business partner Charles, who was working with him by 1788). But CERL dates start of his activity to c.1785 on which makes it hard to link him to confiscations in 1770s.

[Louis-François] et jeune [Pierre-The?ophile) are listed separately as bookseller in the 1781 Almanach de la Librairie. Source data merely indicated 'Barrois, libr.'. Thus edition linked to just Barrois is linked to a non-specific 'Barrois' client.

notes_2: Confiscation register entries to Guyot probably relate to multiple persons. Perhaps some entries for Guiot / Guyot relate to Laurent Guyot / Guiot (1756-1808), the only person of this surname operating in print trade anywhere at this time according to CERL: an engraver and distributor of prints, bookseller, printer and publisher according to CERL (except perhaps his brother and business partner Charles, who was working with him by 1788). But CERL dates start of his activity to c.1785 on which makes it hard to link him to confiscations in 1770s.

The confiscation registers do not explicitly mention 'Nyon jeune' in any entry (though from shape of signatures, it is possible he signed consistently for Nyon aine's consignments). Agents collecting these unattributed consignments are different from those collecting for Saillant et Nyon or Nyon ainé.

Confiscations notes: Turot was presumably the Paris bookseller of that me who appears in STN data (1777) with address in the rue du Roi de Sicile. On line searches reveal Turot (who described himself as a negociant) in 1778 was receiving subscriptions at this address for 'L'Esprit des journaux', the 'Mercure de France' and the 'Affiches, annonces et avid divers, ran the bureau de correspondance for the 'Journal Encyclopedique' and 'L'Esprit de Journaux'. He was possibly the same person as radical journalist Joseph Turot (died 1825), who is listed in CERL and published 'Gazette tionale' in the 1790s. However, further searches in CERL, Worldcat and online have not elicited reveal further information to confirm Turot's identity, and the confiscation associated with him does not relate to his traffic in periodical literature.

notes_1: Only one widow Guillaume is listed in CERL and 1781 Almanach de la librairie. However, Lottin's Catalogue de libraires et imprimeurs de Paris lists two widow Guillaume's entering the trade on the death of their respective husbands in 1778, viz the widow of Laurent-Charles Guillaume and the widow of his nephew Laurent-François Guillaume (who eventually remarried). Laurent-Charles' widow was still trading in 1788. It has mostly been impossible to tell them apart in this dataset.
notes_2: Person not positively identified. This record was created for non-specific references to members of the Guillaume family at stock sales.  Due to context, has been assumed to be a Libraire. Confiscations notes: Signature and me evidence insufficient to tell who is intended by confiscations linked to 'Guillaume'. Several possible people within the book trade.
